Fields.DialogueText: Privet, Kapitan!
Hello, Nerpa. What trouble are you causing today?
Trouble? I would never. I am serene as the waters of Lake Baikal, I'll have you know!
... That said, I could use your help with a little project.
All right. Let's hear it.

Fields.MenuText: This seems a bit out of the blue, even for you.
This should be easy. Just whittle away everything that doesn't look like a bow, right?
Will these bows in any way help us in our fight against the Morganas?

Fields.DialogueText: Kapitan, I am a submarine. Surprises from out of the blue are what I do.
I like your enthusiasm! Perhaps this project will be easier than I thought.
We must look past our immediate concerns from time to time, Kapitan. Life doesn't stop because we're at war.
I think you will find my reasoning sound, Kapitan. I wish to spend some time with you, that we might deepen our bond. Fellow hunters must learn to trust one another, after all.
*ALARM*
We'll pick this up later. Crash dive. All hands to general quarters!
@BATTLE
I'd like your help in making the traditional bows of the Buryat people.
Nerpa, you have a delivery. I'll assume this long, thin crate is for our little project.
Spasibo! This is what I was waiting for. Birch wood and some other important components, straight from Baikalia.
How did you get this stuff anyway? It's not like there's a mail order service for Siberia.
We Belles have our ways, Kapitan. Our homes, physical or spiritual, tend to take great pride in us.

Fields.MenuText: Do everything? How involved is this process, Nerpa?
This is going to take a while, isn't it?
Seems like a bigger deal than your usual projects.

Fields.DialogueText: It's quite extensive, Kapitan, but we have all the time in the world.
Da, but the reward should be worth the wait!
It's a step up from handcrafts, isn't it? That's why I have you here to help!
I'm looking forward to this, Kapitan. Thank you, for humoring me if nothing else.
*ALARM*
Sounds like we have to humor the Morganas first.
Let's show them a proper Baikalia welcome, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
Now let's see... da. It looks like pretty much everything is here. We should be able to do everything here, Kapitan.
Huh. You really are a mystery, you know that?
That, and the People's Commissariat of Tinder Industry also take great pride in me.
Ah, Kapitan, good timing. Pozhaluysta, prisoyedinyaytes' ko mne.
Nerpa, why do you have that hatchet? And should it make me nervous?
Come, Kapitan. You should know I'm handy with such tools.
Now, we are going to set to work on our bows. I purchased cured staves for us to build from.
We're not curing our own wood? That's not like you, Nerpa. You're usually so... hands-on.
You know me quite well, Kapitan, but I thought waiting a year for the wood to cure might be a bit... excessive, shall we say.
I did get some wood to cure myself, though. That counts.
Of course you did. So what do we do?

Fields.MenuText: Nerpa, I have no idea what I'm doing here.
Like... this?
I feel like this is going to end poorly for some reason.

Fields.DialogueText: Let me help, Kapitan. I'll guide your arm.
Khorosho, Kapitan. That's very good.
Nyet, Kapitan, you're doing fine.
Not to worry, though. I will be sure to correct any mistake to ensure a good result.
*ALARM*
Seems we'll have to finish this later.
@BATTLE
We have to mark our shapes out like this... Right, so the general shape of the grip, the curve and length... Here, Kapitan, use this charcoal and follow my lead.
I hope I don't lose my place.
Never fear, Kapitan. You have me to help find it.
Very good, Kapitan. Nice and gentle with the draw knife as you match the outline we drew. Another few strokes and we'll switch to sandpaper.
I have to admit, I didn't expect this to be quite this physical. Keeping the draw knife in alignment is quite nerve-wracking.
I heard a new joke recently! Would you like to hear it? It will take your mind off the work.
You'd tell me regardless. Please, Nerpa, by all means.
The American SIS, the British MI5 and the NKVD send agents to meet in a neutral place. The agencies wish to determine who is the best spy catcher.
They are ordered to go into the nearby woods and capture a mouse.
MI5 goes first. They use their network of informants, interrogate numerous plants. Finally they catch a mouse, convert it to be a double agent, and return empty-handed.
The SIS goes next. The Americans take only a few hours to return with a dead mouse. The mouse had resisted and the agents subdued it with necessary force.
Finally the NKVD's agents go into the woods. They return some thirty minutes later with a badly beaten wolf.

Fields.MenuText: I really wonder how they haven't found a way to send you to Siberia.
Heh, that's probably one of your better ones, Nerpa.
Maybe keep that one between you and me... just in case.

Fields.DialogueText: Because I am effective in combat and serving with an international fleet. Besides, how do you put a submarine in a gulag?
Spasibo, Kapitan! I'm pleased you liked it.
I'm sure the crew would like it, but if you insist, Kapitan.
Whew! All right, sandpaper time?
Da. But first, let's take a break. I'll make some tea.
@BATTLE
The wolf says "I am a mouse, my mother and father were mice. Just make it stop." It's a good joke, da?
*ALARM*
Looks like tea will have to wait.
I'll just make something herbal! Those can steep forever.
So, we're ready for the next stage of our project?
Indeed, Kapitan. I've just inspected the limbs - we have done quite well, I think. We just have to let that first layer of sinew dry for a bit.
I'll take your word for it. You are the expert, after all.
Hardly, Kapitan. I'm as new to this as you are. I just listen to what the spirits tell me.
Ah, yes, you've talked about that a bit before. So the bows have spirits even now?
Da, of course. The wood alone has a spirit to it, and as it becomes a tool of war and of the hunt, it shall develop a spirit that is more than a sum of its parts. As I am.
So you consider the bow to have a spirit similar to a Belle?

Fields.MenuText: This sounds extremely important to you, Nerpa.
Hmm. Definitely not the type of rhetoric I'd expect in this day and age.
You really believe all that?

Fields.DialogueText: It is, Kapitan. It's... part of what I am, I think.
It's an old way of thinking, Kapitan, but that doesn't mean it's wrong.
Of course. How else can I explain myself?
Kapitan, I think our spirits will grow from this, too. So let's do our best, da?
Now, once the horns and bark are softened we should be...
*ALARM*
Of course, our spirits also grow from overcoming adversity.
No shortage of that out here.
@BATTLE
Not on the same scale, Kapitan. Much more goes into a warship than a bow, after all, but yes. In their construction, and through their use, their spirits will grow.
Hell's bells, what is that smell? Is the cook trying to make borscht from rotten beets again?
Hah. That's a good one, Kapitan. No, this is for our bows. I made traditional glue from fish.
I have refined the string nocks - what the Buryats call hershele - and have prepared the horn, sinew, bone, and bark.
Come, Kapitan, let us begin... the horn and bone provide strength on the shoulders, the buryees. Then the second layer of sinew reinforces the side facing the archer.
Ah, right. The sinew I remember.
Finally... ah, right, hold it there. Now we apply bark like this, to guard against moisture.
This is quite the job, isn't it?
Amongst the Buryat, bowyers were highly regarded, and a man's prestige was tied to his skill at hunting and at war with the bow.
Close to done, at least? I should have taken my uniform jacket off before we started.

Fields.MenuText: You don't have to do that, Nerpa. I know how precious that water is to you.
It's fine. I'll just have it run through the wash with the rest of the clothes.

Fields.DialogueText: Worry not, Kapitan. It is well spent on you.
Nyet, Kapitan, I insist. Let me do this for you.
Just leave it to me. I'm glad to do a small favor for you when you've been helping me so much recently.
*ALARM*
Seems we'll have to leave clean up for later. Secure that pot in place and let's go.
@BATTLE
Spasibo. The first is done. Worry not, Kapitan! I'll wash your coat in some of my Baikal water, for good fortune.

Fields.MenuText: Won't that get some... spirit... on it?

Fields.DialogueText: Anything that clings to your coat from this water is a blessing from the lake herself. Cherish it!
Kapitan, do you have a moment?
What is it, Nerpa?
The bows are done drying! We are ready to begin our next stage.
All right, I think I have a little time. What's next?
I intentionally left some material on the baryuul, the handle. I've refined the arrow shelves on each, so now we can work the wood a bit. I'd suggest an animal motif of some kind.

Fields.MenuText: A wolf motif.
A falcon motif.
A horse motif.

Fields.DialogueText: Always a favorite of mine, and very representative. You are our pack leader, after all. We hunt by your command.
Ah, the bird of prey! An interesting choice. Are you perhaps hinting you'd prefer that I was an aircraft carrier, Kapitan? Kidding.
A very good choice! To the Buryats and the greater Mongol peoples, horses were central to everything. They've been such important beasts of war and burden all around the world.
Well, let's get started. This might take a while.
Not to worry, Kapitan! I don't mind spending my free time working on crafts with you.
I went with a nerpa-influenced design, of course. The sleek freshwater seal!
*ALARM*
What little of it we get.
Vse khorosho. We've come to an excellent stopping point.
@BATTLE
And for you?
Well... unless I miss my mark, the cook's actually making borscht again or...
Privet, Kapitan.
Nerpa! Working on another part of our project, I presume?
Of course, Kaptain. I really should come find you when I start, but I get so excited...
Don't slow yourself down for my sake. Your passion's inspiring. Gets the blood rushing.
Kaptain! You can't just say something like that to a maiden. Someone might misunderstand your meaning.
Now, come and hold this. We're going to start twisting and stretching this piece of horse rawhide for our bow strings.
Any particular reason for using horsehide? Something spiritual, maybe?
This is purely practical, Kapitan. On the taiga, in warm weather, bow strings made from cows are preferred. But those do not take cold or water well.
And horsehide does?

Fields.MenuText: Why not just use horsehide all the time?
Very prudent indeed, Nerpa. Well done.
It's all a bit out of my depth, but I trust you to make the right choice.

Fields.DialogueText: Supply? They don't only raise horses for bows.
Spasibo, Kapitan! And this way there is no need to switch, unless we change latitudes.
Your trust honors me, Kapitan! I'll do my best with it.
Oh, speaking of horses, I heard a new joke. So some peasants go to petition Lenin...
*ALARM*
Grr! Those Rusalki will pay if my bow strings are messed up. Come, Kapitan. Let's teach them some manners.
@BATTLE
Khorosho, that's correct. So the Buryats would switch their bowstrings season after season. Since we are on the water all the time, I thought horsehide would be prudent.
All right, do these look done to you? What's the final verdict?
I think we're done, Kapitan. With the bows, anyway. We still have some other tasks to accomplish, but...

Fields.MenuText: Now I just need to figure out how to shoot a bow and we're golden.
I'm not sure what we can hunt with these from a deck of a submarine, but I'm glad all the same.
I'm still unsure about this. But if you're happy, I'm happy.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't worry, Kapitan! When I'm done with you you'll be shooting like a true Buryat.
I have some ideas about that, Kapitan, but it'll be a surprise.
You'll enjoy it when we reap the fruits of our efforts.
For now, let's work on the waterproof cases for our bows - important for keeping them safely aboard a submarine.
Sounds like a plan. I assume that's what all this leather is for?
Khorosho.
There's so many factors to all this. It's fascinating.
Good. I'd hate to bore you.
I don't think there's any chance of that.
@BATTLE
I'm pleased beyond words! They really do look wonderful, and they should handle tension well.
*ALARM*
With or without the Rusalki.
What's that noise? It's driving me mad.
Comrade Kapitan, Nerpa's up on deck with those bows you've been working on. I'd wager that's it.
Thank you. I'll go see what she's up to.
Privet, Kapitan. I was just about to come look for you.
Well, you've somehow managed to vibrate the whole ship with your bow string. Of course I'm going to investigate.
Sometimes I don't know my own strength. But come! This is a good chance to teach you to shoot a bow like a Buryat.
Now, hold the bow in your left hand, then draw the string back hard to behind your ear. When we've finished everything, the pressure will be entirely on a special thumb ring.
Thumb ring? How much are these going to cost us? We don't have much of a budget for anything fancy.
Not to worry, Kapitan. They're traditionally made out of bone. Now, cover your thumb with your index finger... da, like that.

Fields.MenuText: Are you sure this is right? It feels quite... odd.
Did you really wake up with all this information? Or did you research it?
I think I have it, but I really need to try it with an arrow.

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan. You'll get the hang of it in no time.
I woke up with it, Kapitan. It's as much a part of me as the waters of Lake Baikal.
Khorosho. Very good! You took to it like a seal pup to water.
Kapitan... I think we need to suspend our lesson and get below.
*ALARM*
Hellspawns. Move it. Good instinct, Nerpa.
@BATTLE
That's the basics of the Mongolian release, the archery technique of the steppes. The covering from the index finger prevents the arrow from deviating to the left.
Idti dalshe net uzhe mochi, pred nim rasstilalsya Baikal...
That's a familiar tune... and a familiar voice.
Kapitan, did my voice draw you in like a siren?
You certainly have a striking singing voice, Nerpa. No one can deny that.
Bol'shoye spasibo, Kapitan. Thank you very much for your kind words.
Just calling it like I hear it. I assume you're singing while you work?
I am making arrows. I have bone for arrowheads, should we decide to hunt.
I also thought it would be appropriate to make war arrows for our quivers. I cannot do such work on my own, so I asked for help around the fleet. They might not be able to pierce a Rusalka...
But they look pretty nasty all the same.

Fields.MenuText: Like what? I still don't think Morganas are going to flinch from an arrow.
If we run into any knights in plate armor, I suppose we'll be ready.
Good point. Walrus or moose would take something with a little more weight to it.

Fields.DialogueText: You never know with the Rusalki, but we should probably stick to my torpedoes all the same.
Heheh, another good joke. Though practical. The world has seen stranger things than a knight in this age.
Precisely, Kapitan. I was thinking about some of the thicker-skinned fish as well.
I am also going to make some special arrows unique to the steppes and taiga, but... I am afraid I'll have to tell you about them another time.
I like an early warning for my early warnings.
Let's sink them quickly. Don't want to let the glue for the fletching dry out!
@BATTLE
Indeed. They might also be good for hunting more serious prey.
*ALARM*
*KNOCK*
Comrade Kapitan. There are noises like pressure leaks all over the boat. Starshina Nikolaev wanted me to get you.
Right, I'm... wait. That doesn't sound like pressure... Where's Nerpa?
I don't think I've seen her. She may be topside.
Tell the XO to get everyone calmed down. I want a leak check done on the whole boat. I'm going topside.
Aye-aye, Kapitan.
*WHISTLE*
Nerpa what the hell is that racket?
Buryat singing arrows! I was just testing the different arrowhead patterns I've cut.
Well, give the crew some sort of warning first. Some of the sailors thought we had a leak somewhere.
Prosti, Kapitan, I didn't mean to cause alarm. Come have a look at these arrows, though! I think I've perfected my design.
What are they, exactly?
Bone arrowheads with channels cut into them to produce various pitches of loud whistling noise. They were useful tools for hunting and for warfare.

Fields.MenuText: I hate to ask, but why did you make those? We have radios now.
Hmm, could be interesting. Can you make me one as a good luck charm?
That makes a lot of sense. I've heard of using barking dogs to spook game.

Fields.DialogueText: And if the radios go down? Rusalki can't listen in on these. Not until they're sticking out of them.
Of course, Kapitan! The best charms make their own luck.
It is a similar concept, but you can't make your own dogs!
*ALARM*
Sounds like we have incoming. I wonder if your arrows spooked the Morganas?
Worth a try. The Rusalki work in mysterious ways, Kapitan. Sometimes to our benefit!
@BATTLE
For hunting you could spook game with them. When the Mongol armies went to war, their generals would direct the battle with whistling arrows. Each pitch meant something specific.
You know, I really shouldn't be surprised any more, but yet I manage. All right, Nerpa.
You called, Kapitan?
What's with all these spools of... whatever the hell this is, and why are they clogging up the passageways?
Oh, I'm sorry, Kapitan. Mne zhal'. I was going to move them soon. They're spools of linen fishing line.
Taking up deep-sea angling?

Fields.MenuText: I hate surprises, but as long as you get them stowed out of the way...
Hmmm... you look suspicious. Why is that, Nerpa?
I'm concerned... but I've learned to look the other way.

Fields.DialogueText: You'll like this one, Kapitan. I promise.
Why, I'm as pure as fresh Baikal snow!
That's the spirit, Kapitan! A watched samovar never boils.
I'll start clearing these now. Do you mind lending a hand?
Fine, if it means getting the passageways clear. There's about to be a lot of running around.
@BATTLE
It's... actually something of a surprise, Kapitan, so do you mind if I keep it a secret for now?
*ALARM*
A little something to eat, Kapitan?
Funny. You look and sound like Nerpa, but you're clearly an angel of mercy.
Some say that we are! I've made some shuba and fresh-brewed tea.
Dressed Herring, in English... or herring in a fur coat, to some of our sailors.
That is... extremely purple.

Fields.MenuText: Ah, just like someone's babushka made it.
This is... huh. This is actually pretty good.
Mmm. It's certainly... nutritious.

Fields.DialogueText: That's quite the compliment, Kapitan! Especially considering I have no babushka to learn from. Well, not in the traditional sense.
Eat as much as you'd like! I made enough for us to share with some leftovers.
All those nutrients are good for you! I have to keep you in good health, Kapitan.
I have some good rye bread, too. Can I get anything else?
Nerpa, it's fine. Sit down and eat. You've had your eyes on the shuba since you brought it here.
If you insist! But even the taste of shuba is nothing compared to watching someone enjoy it.
@BATTLE
That will be the beets! Dig in, Kapitan.
Shuba?
*ALARM*
Will this... keep?
Of course! It's a salad, after all.
Nerpa... not that I mind, but normally if you're holding someone's hand, you do it with one hand.
Oh, I'm sorry, Kapitan. I should have said something before I started.
Started what, exactly?

Fields.MenuText: Nerpa, that's my ring finger, not my thumb.
Oh did you finish shaping them?
What do those do again?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh! What a silly mistake that would be.
Da, Kapitan. I'm going to carve some motifs into the bone when I'm done shaping and sizing them to match our bows.
You use the thumb ring to hold and release the bowstring in Buryat and Mongolian-style archery. Easier on the skin.
We're getting close to the end, Kapitan!
I wonder where this is all going to go... but I've been enjoying spending the time with you all the same.
Spasibo, Kapitan. I've been enjoying your company as well.
@BATTLE
I'm sizing you for your yahan erkhe - your thumb ring for our little archery project.
*ALARM*
Through better and worse.
Kapitan! Here, put this on.
Is this the thumb ring?
Da. I just need to check it on your actual thumb. It should sit over your first knuckle... right, like that.
Seems like it fits nice and snug. Now I see what you mean about how the string is held.
Khorosho. I took the liberty of making our quivers on my own, so with that... we're done.

Fields.MenuText: I wasn't humoring you. I had fun too.
I wasn't quite sure what to think at the start, but I enjoyed it.
As long as it keeps your morale up, I'm happy to help.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, wonderful! I have a new hunting partner!
That's a risk I'm always happy to take!
You just might learn something along the way, too. Everyone wins!
When you have some time, let's get some archery practice in.
Sure thing. Just as soon as I clear this damned paperwork.
Ha! All work and no play makes you a model Soviet.
So what does that make you?
A happy seal, Kapitan. Nothing more, nothing less.
@BATTLE
I am excited to try our bows, and... I wanted to thank you for doing this with me. Even if you were humoring me, it was... nice.
*ALARM*
Aren't nerpas freshwater seals?
The only ones. That makes me unique!
Reaaaady... Loose!
Hah. Bullseye.
Nice shot, Nerpa. You seem to be taking to this like a seal to water.
Of course, Kapitan. You're doing well, too. I know the Mongolian release likely isn't very intuitive.
It's simple and makes sense. I think I'm doing fine. I had a thought, though.
What's that, Kapitan?
Well, these are weapons for hunting and war. Obviously they won't help our war effort, so that leaves hunting... but what can we hunt?

Fields.MenuText: Why am I suddenly concerned, Nerpa?
What kind of... testing?
Your ideas usually pan out. Let me know when it's ready.

Fields.DialogueText: Have faith in me, Kapitan. I have plenty in you!
Oh, just some experiments I've been trying. I'll have it ready to show you soon.
Hehe. Spasibo! I'll live up to your confidence in me.
*ALARM*
I suppose it's time for torpedo practice now, eh, Kapitan?
That's like archery, right?
@BATTLE
I've been working on that, actually. I've got some things together for testing.
All of the fun and none of the strain!
*SPLASH*
What is she up to now?
Comrade Kapitan, you seem to be getting to know the First Comrade quite well.
You're an experienced sailor. You know how a captain needs to know their ship.
Da, Kapitan. Then you'll know she's on deck already.
That I do. I'll go see what Nerpa's up to.
Chert. I shot too high again. Ah, Kapitan! Come, I'm trying to fish.
With your bow?
Look here. I have made some arrowheads that will hook into flesh, and set the shafts up with a linen line so I can bring them in.
That's... just crazy enough to work.

Fields.MenuText: No one can say you dream small.
Seems like an interesting idea all the same.
I bet we can increase our supplies of fresh food with this.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course not, Kapitan! What are dreams for?
That's because it works marvelously!
My thoughts exactly, Kapitan. And we can chum for sharks, too!
Come, you try too.
I don't know, Nerpa. This looks pretty silly.
All the more reason to bow fish together, Kapitan. Things look much less silly when done by more than one person. Just look at the Soviet Union.
Got my bow?
Da. Of course! Now, aim it...
It's been done by people all around the world... but perhaps never as ambitiously as I.
*ALARM*
... That way.
@BATTLE
Kapitan, the cooks send their regards for the fresh fish. The crew seem quite excited, too.
Seems we've managed to get the hang of this bowfishing thing.
Aiming low, then shooting lower than that seems to be the real trick of it.
So... what's on your mind? You have that look you get when you have an idea cooking.
Well, Kapitan... I was thinking. I think we should have a bet.
A bet? All right, what's the wager?

Fields.MenuText: I feel like the odds are stacked against me.
You realize that this means war.
At the very least, it'll probably improve morale.

Fields.DialogueText: Not at all! You've just as much experience in this task as I do.
I'd expect nothing less from you! That's what makes it fun.
You can admit that you'll enjoy this competition, you know. I can see it in your eyes!
Very well! The challenge shall begin as soon as we can find some good waters.
And time in our patrol schedule, of course.
Oh, da. I forgot about that. That's probably important.
Just a little.
*ALARM*
That too.
On to importance!
@BATTLE
You and me, bowfishing one on one. Whoever brings the biggest fish in wins. The loser has to cook for the winner and the whole crew.
Ready for our contest, Kapitan?
As ready as I'll ever be, Nerpa. Let's get topside and get to work.

Fields.MenuText: So is it by total weight of all fish caught, or single individual fish?
How limited are your Belle abilities in this case?
I have a bad feeling about this for some reason.

Fields.DialogueText: Biggest single fish is what we agreed on, Kapitan. Small fries are small even in a school.
I don't think I have any that will give me a leg up. That I know of.
Cheer up, Kapitan! You'll grump the fish away.
Got all the fishing arrows set up?
You may inspect them for foul play, if you wish.
That won't be necessary. If I can't trust you of all Belles, we've already lost the war. Never mind this contest.
I appreciate your trust, Kapitan.
Damn it. The Morganas are going to scare away all the fish!
Any questions about the rules again?
*ALARM*
Nyet! I will not have our contest be a casualty!
@BATTLE
I didn't even know white fish of any size could get that big.
I was surprised too. I thought I'd hooked a whale or something.

Fields.MenuText: Ukha. Simple, delicious, Russian.
Fish and chips, of course. Always good for a crowd of seafaring lads and lasses.
Heringsstipp should send the crew away full and ready for work.

Fields.DialogueText: Rather like myself! Ahem... my favorite. I look forward to it.
I think that dish exists in every culture. Who can blame the world for uniting in the joys of deep-fried fish?
Hmmm... sounds German, yes, Kapitan? That's always filling.
I'll save you a plate. I'd like to eat with you once you're done.
Sounds good. I'll come find you once everyone's been served.
I'm excited to taste your cooking, Kapitan. I'll be first in line.
@BATTLE
So, Kapitan, you handled your defeat honorably. May I ask what you're going to cook?
*ALARM*
And last to the sea floor!
Something on your mind, Nerpa? You look deep in thought.
I've had fun making our bows, and fishing, and I even got you to cook for me. But I wonder... there should be a way to apply all this to our real work, da?
Well, Buryat archery techniques were certainly a martial tradition in addition to part of hunting culture.

Fields.MenuText: Have you considered you're trying to take the wrong lessons from archery?
When you hunt big game, you pick the appropriate tool for the job. It doesn't change the rest of hunting.
You really think all of this training of the self hasn't improved your mindset, if nothing else?

Fields.DialogueText: Hmm. I haven't, Kapitan. That's... hmm. I'll need to think about that.
The appropriate tool for the job... hmm.
You have a point, but how to apply that to more practical matters than just feeding ourselves?
Hmm. I need some quiet so I can think about all this. I'm close to figuring something out, but I...
*ALARM*
Chert. I suppose we'll need to go through the Rusalki so I can get the time I need.
All the more reason to dispatch them quickly.
Aye-aye, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
But you can't hunt Rusalki with a bow, Kapitan. I would have tried it by now if I thought it possible.
Have you seen Nerpa?
Comrade Kapitan, no. We had assumed she was with you. Starshina.
Da, tovarishch?
Comrade Kapitan wishes to know where Comrade Nerpa is. Any ideas?
I believe she went up on deck when we surfaced to snorkel. I can check with my lookouts.
No, that's all right. I'll go myself. Carry on.
Ah, Kapitan. I'm sorry, am I missing something?
No, I was looking for you. You're pretty obvious when you're missing.
How do you mean, Kapitan?
Well, it's strange when you're not close to hand or up to some sort of project. I get worried when you're subdued like this.

Fields.MenuText: You mean... feel it, more so than just fire a torpedo?
Why limit it to just your torpedoes? Everything we've learned together can apply to our fight in the ocean.
Then let's go hunting. You, me, the crew. We'll hunt the Buryat way.

Fields.DialogueText: Da. That's it - to feel it.
The average Rusalka can be baited like a fish, can she not?
Otlichno! You always know how to help.
That settles it. Come, Kapitan. We'll track the game, and spook them for the rest of the fleet to finish off.
Just the thing to get her back to her perky self.
@BATTLE
Ah... nyet, Kapitan. I'm all right. I'm just... I think I've figured something out. I wish... to loose my torpedoes like arrows.
*ALARM*
Comrade Kapitan, the bridge is clear and the ship is rigged for diving. Scouts from the fleet detected an enemy battle group northwest of here. We have their last coordinates.
Here we go. Conn. Take us down - ten degrees down bubble. Make your depth twenty meters and move us towards the enemy. Nice and slow.
Ten degrees down bubble, twenty meters deep...
Torpedoes loaded, Kapitan.
Open outer doors. No sense making too much noise as we get closer...
Ready, Kapitan... I can detect the Rusalka battle group.
Captain, we're at depth.
Even her out, zero bubble. Rig for silent running. Let's get in nice and close and dig the knife in deep.
I admit... I am a bit nervous, Kapitan.
Nothing we haven't done before, even if we are out here without cover.
Kapitan... we're making range. The Morgana battle group is closer than expected.
Periscope. Yep, they're out there... Right, get me firing solutions. We dump a full spread of torpedoes.
A full spread of torpedoes will certainly get the enemy's attention.
Firing solutions ready, Kapitan. Just let me... focus...
Fire when ready, Nerpa.
Launch.
Torpedoes away.
Bring us around and take us deep. Twenty degrees down bubble. The second we level out, cavitate. I want to beat our top underwater speed by at least two knots.

Fields.MenuText: Well, I think we managed to poke the hornet's nest.
Well? How do you... you know, feel?
Was it good for you too?

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan. A perfect stalk and kill.
I feel... good. Relaxed, even.
Kapitan! There are people around. Someone might misunderstand.
Captain. We're close to the fleet.
Bring us up to radio depth. We have a fleet to sink.
@BATTLE
Aye-aye, Captain.
Kapitan. There you are.
Looking for me?
Da... I wanted to talk to you.
Oh? What about?
It's... I wanted to thank you again. For... everything.
Don't think anything about it, Nerpa. I like seeing you smile and I like it when you're happy.
Was I not smiling recently?
No, but why risk you not smiling at some point? You have a smile for the world, and I want to make sure you're in a place to share it.
Kapitan... spasibo. But you're wrong on one thing.
Oh? What's that?

Fields.MenuText: Nerpa... I think I have one for you too.
That's a little too cute.
Heh. Well, I hope you don't mind if I hoard it.

Fields.DialogueText: Kapitan... oh, now I'm embarrassed.
Tee hee. Nothing wrong with that.
By all means, Kapitan. It never tarnishes.
I... ah... I need to go. Hunting and all that.
A peck on the cheek certainly warms me up.
This particular smile is only for you.
*ALARM*
Here. A token of my appreciation.
It's cold out there, Kapitan. Just let me know if you'd like more.
@BATTLE
